The OU courses are of excellent quality,
so these are well worth looking at
I was impressed by the range that was available
If you are interested in Astronomy and Space I suggest  In the Night sky : Orion,
there is a lot of crossover with other courses,  which is sometimes a good thing
And if you need to discuss something further you could always ask here on the forum.
How effective are these courses?
I would expect the definition of "effective" to differ between students
Perhaps you can describe the effects you're looking for?
I would also add that effectiveness is typically more dependent on the student than on the lecture itself.
Lectures generally gives you an idea of a topic with some examples.
However mastery of the subject requires additional engagement with the subject.
At least if you want to go beyond just the next exam.
The effectiveness of the courses depends on 80% of the student
The teacher can teach him, give interesting tasks, use interactive teaching methods
However, if a student does not want to study, the courses will not be practical.
Of course, not all people are like that.
Some people need to spend several hours reading books and assimilating the material.
When I was in college, I couldn't pass physics, no matter how hard I tried.
First of all, see if the formed courses are suitable for you.
That is certainly true.
Most students do not realize that a lecture is supposed to be a general guidance to the material, and is not the material itself.
Then asking how effective the courses are seems like it's only going to be 20% effective.
Also, you can't have two accounts here
especially if you're going to use one of them as a sockpuppet to comment on the other's posts
doubly especially if you're going to use them to advertise crap websites

or I can spam-ban both, if you're not here for science discussion.

There are many, includng SciShow and Phisics Girl for a variety of quick explanations
At the other end of the spectrum, many universities have recorded lectures by professors
for example Leonard Susskind of Stanford. For science news, a site like Phys.org or another is good
there is not a formula for research, except be persistent.
none of these channels are adequate substitutes for your independent investigation
Also Bite Sized Psyche is a one of my top 3 science channels
Nice compressed psychological studies and observations summarized nicely.
I just discovered Animalogic, very entertaining

Awesom daily life science from Joe Hanson
Channels like, "It's Okay To Be Smart" and "Physics Girl" are usually humorous and hard to take seriously
I would not recommend them if you want a serious lecture
Channels like Fermilab and Veritasium are good for more complicated lectures and in-depth explanations of concepts rather than quick overviews of them

uses some new animation techniques
and it isn't afraid to change some well established concepts if it helps understanding
Actually, changing these concepts is a bold step that may be a way forward in the pedagogy.
It doesn't follow historical development but instead seeks to present the finished article that is modern GR efficiently.
It isn't afraid to change some well established concepts and makes no mention of this.

the geodesic equations with some thoroughly shameful exploitations that could leave you screaming

Here is very good source of information about conferences, science events, workshops and other similar stuff.

This is really nice!
they don't specify how related is "related."
while they all point out that the peer review process involves scrutiny from people in "related" fields
Such people have familiarity with the techniques and procedures of the experiments
In my own experience it’s a closely-related field.
Such people have familiarity with any theory being discussed
Reviewers generally volunteer their time
it’s not reasonable to expect them to get up to speed in an area not in their wheelhouse in order to do peer review.
You probably wouldn’t be the only one doing such interdisciplinary work
But it’s possible you could have reviewers from both disciplines, each looking at their own area of expertise
Again that leaves the question of how closely is closely.
It’s people who have published in the same research area
when I submitted a paper on laser cooling and trapping, AFAIK it was reviewed by others doing laser cooling and trapping.
This is an area within atomic and optical physics.
Journals and conferences often provide sorting categories or topics
In my experience, reviewers would be publishing in the same category.
Generally, a prospective reviewer needs to have an active publication record in the field
though not always, sometimes grad students can review
Generally, I would expect a reviewer for a virology paper to have worked/published on viruses
I wouldn't send a genomics/bioinformatics paper to and old school physiologist and vice versa.
although who I actually send it to is at my discretion
I often try to find a reviewer with background on methodological side of things
the approach is sound and ideally someone in field from for which conclusions are drawn
That is not always possible as you often have to go through a lot of potential reviewers
you often have to go through a lot of potential reviewers before you find someone who agrees to review it

The first obstacle sounds like the biggest.
Wanting to educate others while lacking your own knowledge seems counterproductive.
Why not start with a SINGLE, identifiable goal you can reach
Educating yourself, removing the gaps in your knowledgeis one of the smartest things you could ever do.
and giving yourself more high-quality information to work with is one of the smartest things you could ever do.
Ignorance is a spectrum, and we're all on it,
the more we can learn the better and more informed our choices are.

The size alone is remarkable
the insights into the evolution of eukaryotes provided by its "membranous pouch" containng the organisms DNA are intriguing
But, wow! what a stash of DNA!
Bacteria don't have cell nuclei.
That is plausibly a step through which life passed in moving from prokaryotes (no nuclei) to eukaryotes
Isn't it just another line of evolution from whatever common ancestor we share?
The bacterial DNA is not actually distributed throughout the cell.
BTW, the article says that their ribosomes are in the same pouch, with the DNA
This is crucially different from the eukaryotes whose ribosomes are outside the nuclei.
Looks more like a superficial resemblance to me.
I suppose because they found an ecological niche that still works for them
The "missing link" does not refer its evolution but to our knowledge.
Haven't had time to search.
Yes, but I don't see your point
This does not contradict my observations.
Again, I am not sure what you are driving at.
I've offered an explanation of why this was described as a missing link
It is incidental that the ribosomes are also in the pouch.
We don't even know that it remained unchanged or changed very little
Maybe they evolved relatively recently.
That was my assumption, from the little bit I've read on it
Of course, it's still a descendant of our common family tree, but on a twig very, very far from the one on which we're hanging.
There has to be some observed data to prompt a hypothesis
Okay. When? From what?
I'm not aware of one that posits a recent origin for this species
That doesn't mean it's wrong, just that I don't know enough
Yes, not enough data.
The only knowledge is that they evolved some time during the last 3-4 billion years
Depends what you consider 'very long'.
And just because they live in conjunction with mangroves now, we can't assume that they have not changed habitats and food sources sometime
Let's give the researchers a couple of days to study on it.
Yes, 75 million years I consider not long at all on the 3-4 billion years scale
Of course they have changed their habitat many times
This is evolution.
The unknown we are talking about is, when during this evolution they evolved this peculiar compartmentation.
How about on the bacterial scale?
Mangrove trees live over 100 years each, while bacteria live no more than a day
The turnover, and thus mutation opportunity and thus evolution, is considerably faster on that scale.
But anyway, their evolution occurring faster they could evolve this feature really recently.
How about in the last million years, for example?
I hope somebody who actually knows tells us pretty soon.
Don't hold your breath.
The ability to gain that size is based on at least two important factors
First, they are sessile, so mobility is not an issue as for many other bacteria
The second is that are able to store nutrients which allows them to survive nutrient fluctuations, despite being sessile.
however until this recent discovery they all were less than 1 mm in size and didn't have a DNA pouch
I would have to look at the lit again, but I am fairly certain that Thimargarita  most species had elaborate internal membrane structures
I am fairly certain that the DNA in the earlier detected species was also well localized
something similar has been observed in another giant bacterium
It is quite likely that membrane structures are involved
but they might be difficult to properly visualize
It is therefore possible that either the newly developed species is more compartmentalized or that the compartments are easier visualized as they are larger.
It should also be noted that it is sometime reported that DNA in bacteria are free-floating.
This is actually not the case as high-resolution analyses does suggest that bacteria organize their internal organelles to quite some degree
and are bound to the membrane in a specific way
This is more obvious in large, elongated cells, but is likely somewhat universal, if underappreciated
but we see the basic principles that might be related to that level of organization in most bacteria
I have to say that sub-cellular anatomy might be one of my weaker areas
when it comes to bacteria as I have not been doing these types of projects for quite a long time now
I am not sure where the current literature is at.
